entries.etymology: Modern compound term describing ties between Africa (esp. Nile corridor) and the Levant.
entries.definition: Describes peoples, trade, or cultural links spanning Northeast Africa and the Levant in antiquity.
entries.usage_notes: Useful umbrella term; definitions vary by scholar and period.

entries.etymology: Via Latin gentilis ‘of a gens’; in Scripture maps to Heb. goy/goyim, Gk. ethnos/ethnē.
entries.definition: Context-dependent term for ‘nations/peoples’; sometimes used of Israel as a nation, sometimes of non-Israelite nations.
entries.usage_notes: Meaning shifts with period and context; not a fixed biological category.

entries.definition: Northern district associated with mixed populations including Israelites and non-israelites; used to frame the setting of Jesus’s early ministry.
entries.usage_notes: Indicates a border/mixed region rather than a fixed ethnic label. There are New-Testament references corresponding to these deductions

entries.definition: Israelite ethnonym linked to Judah/Judea; sometimes denotes members/partisans of the Judean polity.
entries.usage_notes: In Second Temple usage, political/cultural sense can appear alongside lineage. This term is exclusively applied to descendants of Judah only, but later became ascribed to the South Kingdom when speaking generally

entries.definition: Peoples south of Egypt (Nubia/Kush) known from biblical and classical sources; frequently interact with Egypt and Israel.
entries.usage_notes: ‘Ethiopian’ in Greek sources can be broad; usage varies by author and era. For example, historians were not able to distinguish Coptics, Israelites, and Nubians from one another
